metadata.title: Lists and tables | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page covering lists and tables, which present data in one or more columns of rows. The document provides best practices for content, style, and platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS.

content.text: Lists and tables
Lists and tables present data in one or more columns of rows.

content.description: An illustration showing a grouped table view with iOS-style design. The image depicts a light gray/white table view with rounded corners containing multiple sections. The table has a header section labeled 'Grouped Table View Header' at the top, followed by three rows labeled 'Table Row 1', 'Table Row 2', and 'Table Row 3'. Each row has a chevron/disclosure indicator (>) on the right side indicating navigation capability. At the bottom is a 'Grouped Table View Footer' section. The entire table has a subtle shadow and rounded corners consistent with iOS grouped table view styling.
content.composition: Vertical stack of table elements with header at top, three rows in middle, footer at bottom, all contained within a rounded rectangle container
colorPalette: #FF6B6B (coral/salmon accent color on header and footer)
content.technicalDetails: iOS-style grouped table view UI mockup showing standard UITableView grouped style appearance
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the visual structure of a grouped table view on iOS, which is a key UI pattern discussed in the documentation

content.text: A table or list can represent data that's organized in groups or hierarchies, and it can support user interactions like selecting, adding, deleting, and reordering. Apps and games in all platforms can use tables to present content and options; many apps use lists to express an overall information hierarchy and help people navigate it. For example, iOS Settings uses a hierarchy of lists to help people choose options, and several apps — such as Mail in iPadOS and macOS — use a table within a split view.

Sometimes, people need to work with complex data in a multicolumn table or a spreadsheet. Apps that offer productivity tasks often use a table to represent various characteristics or attributes of the data in separate, sortable columns.
Best practices

Prefer displaying text in a list or table. A table can include any type of content, but the row-based format is especially well suited to making text easy to scan and read. If you have items that vary widely in size — or you need to display a large number of images — consider using a collection instead.

structuredContent.leadBold: Prefer displaying text in a list or table.
structuredContent.remainder: A table can include any type of content, but the row-based format is especially well suited to making text easy to scan and read. If you have items that vary widely in size — or you need to display a large number of images — consider using a collection instead.

content.text: Let people edit a table when it makes sense. People appreciate being able to reorder a list, even if they can't add or remove items. In iOS and iPadOS, people must enter an edit mode before they can select table items.

structuredContent.leadBold: Let people edit a table when it makes sense.
structuredContent.remainder: People appreciate being able to reorder a list, even if they can't add or remove items. In iOS and iPadOS, people must enter an edit mode before they can select table items.

content.text: Provide appropriate feedback when people select a list item. The feedback can vary depending on whether selecting the item reveals a new view or toggles the item's state. In general, a table that helps people navigate through a hierarchy persistently highlights the selected row to clarify the path people are taking. In contrast, a table that lists options often highlights a row only briefly before adding an image — such as a checkmark — indicating that the item is selected.

structuredContent.leadBold: Provide appropriate feedback when people select a list item.
structuredContent.remainder: The feedback can vary depending on whether selecting the item reveals a new view or toggles the item's state. In general, a table that helps people navigate through a hierarchy persistently highlights the selected row to clarify the path people are taking. In contrast, a table that lists options often highlights a row only briefly before adding an image — such as a checkmark — indicating that the item is selected.

content.text: Content

Keep item text succinct so row content is comfortable to read. Short, succinct text can help minimize truncation and wrapping, making text easier to read and scan. If each item consists of a large amount of text, consider alternatives that help you avoid displaying over-large table rows. For example, you could list item titles only, letting people choose an item to reveal its content in a detail view.

structuredContent.leadBold: Keep item text succinct so row content is comfortable to read.
structuredContent.remainder: Short, succinct text can help minimize truncation and wrapping, making text easier to read and scan. If each item consists of a large amount of text, consider alternatives that help you avoid displaying over-large table rows. For example, you could list item titles only, letting people choose an item to reveal its content in a detail view.

content.text: Consider ways to preserve readability of text that might otherwise get clipped or truncated. When a table is narrow — for example, if people can vary its width — you want content to remain recognizable and easy to read. Sometimes, an ellipsis in the middle of text can make an item easier to distinguish because it preserves both the beginning and the end of the content.

structuredContent.leadBold: Consider ways to preserve readability of text that might otherwise get clipped or truncated.
structuredContent.remainder: When a table is narrow — for example, if people can vary its width — you want content to remain recognizable and easy to read. Sometimes, an ellipsis in the middle of text can make an item easier to distinguish because it preserves both the beginning and the end of the content.

content.text: Use descriptive column headings in a multicolumn table. Use nouns or short noun phrases with title-style capitalization, and don't add ending punctuation. If you don't include a column heading in a single-column table view, use a label or a header to help people understand the context.

structuredContent.leadBold: Use descriptive column headings in a multicolumn table.
structuredContent.remainder: Use nouns or short noun phrases with title-style capitalization, and don't add ending punctuation. If you don't include a column heading in a single-column table view, use a label or a header to help people understand the context.

content.text: Style

Choose a table or list style that coordinates with your data and platform. Some styles use visual details to help communicate grouping and hierarchy or to provide specific experiences. In iOS and iPadOS, for example, the grouped style uses headers, footers, and additional space to separate groups of data; the elliptical style available in watchOS makes items appear as if they're rolling off a rounded surface as people scroll; and macOS defines a bordered style that uses alternating row backgrounds to help make large tables easier to use. For developer guidance, see ListStyle.

structuredContent.leadBold: Choose a table or list style that coordinates with your data and platform.
structuredContent.remainder: Some styles use visual details to help communicate grouping and hierarchy or to provide specific experiences. In iOS and iPadOS, for example, the grouped style uses headers, footers, and additional space to separate groups of data; the elliptical style available in watchOS makes items appear as if they're rolling off a rounded surface as people scroll; and macOS defines a bordered style that uses alternating row backgrounds to help make large tables easier to use. For developer guidance, see ListStyle.

content.text: Choose a row style that fits the information you need to display. For example, you might need to display a small image in the leading end of a row, followed by a brief explanatory label. Some platforms provide built-in row styles you can use to arrange content in list rows, such as the UIListContentConfiguration API you can use to lay out content in a list's rows, headers, and footers in iOS, iPadOS, and tvOS.

structuredContent.leadBold: Choose a row style that fits the information you need to display.
structuredContent.remainder: For example, you might need to display a small image in the leading end of a row, followed by a brief explanatory label. Some platforms provide built-in row styles you can use to arrange content in list rows, such as the UIListContentConfiguration API you can use to lay out content in a list's rows, headers, and footers in iOS, iPadOS, and tvOS.

content.text: Use an info button only to reveal more information about a row's content. An info button — called a detail disclosure button when it appears in a list row — doesn't support navigation through a hierarchical table or list. If you need to let people drill into a list or table row's subviews, use a disclosure indicator accessory control. For developer guidance, see UITableViewCell.AccessoryType.disclosureIndicator.

structuredContent.leadBold: Use an info button only to reveal more information about a row's content.
structuredContent.remainder: An info button — called a detail disclosure button when it appears in a list row — doesn't support navigation through a hierarchical table or list. If you need to let people drill into a list or table row's subviews, use a disclosure indicator accessory control. For developer guidance, see UITableViewCell.AccessoryType.disclosureIndicator.

content.description: A side-by-side comparison showing two list row accessories: an info button (circle with 'i' icon) and a disclosure indicator (chevron arrow). Each shows the visual appearance and explains their different purposes.
content.narrativeWalkthrough: The diagram shows two common list row accessories side by side. On the left is an info button (a blue circle containing a lowercase 'i'), which is used to show additional details about the current item without navigating away. On the right is a disclosure indicator (a gray chevron pointing right), which indicates that tapping will navigate to a new view showing child content or the next level in a hierarchy.

captions.text: An info button shows details about a list item; it doesn't support navigation.
A disclosure indicator reveals the next level in a hierarchy; it doesn't show details about the item.

content.text: Avoid adding an index to a table that displays controls — like disclosure indicators — in the trailing ends of its rows. An index typically consists of the letters in an alphabet, displayed vertically at the trailing side of a list. People can jump to a specific section in the list by choosing the index letter that maps to it. Because both the index and elements like disclosure indicators appear on the trailing side of a list, it can be difficult for people to use one element without activating the other.

structuredContent.leadBold: Avoid adding an index to a table that displays controls — like disclosure indicators — in the trailing ends of its rows.
structuredContent.remainder: An index typically consists of the letters in an alphabet, displayed vertically at the trailing side of a list. People can jump to a specific section in the list by choosing the index letter that maps to it. Because both the index and elements like disclosure indicators appear on the trailing side of a list, it can be difficult for people to use one element without activating the other.

content.text: Platform considerations
iOS, iPadOS, visionOS

Use an info button only to reveal more information about a row's content. An info button — called a detail disclosure button when it appears in a list row — doesn't support navigation through a hierarchical table or list. If you need to let people drill into a list or table row's subviews, use a disclosure indicator accessory control. For developer guidance, see UITableViewCell.AccessoryType.disclosureIndicator.

structuredContent.leadBold: Use an info button only to reveal more information about a row's content.
structuredContent.remainder: An info button — called a detail disclosure button when it appears in a list row — doesn't support navigation through a hierarchical table or list. If you need to let people drill into a list or table row's subviews, use a disclosure indicator accessory control. For developer guidance, see UITableViewCell.AccessoryType.disclosureIndicator.

content.text: macOS

When it provides value, let people click a column heading to sort a table view based on that column. If people click the heading of a column that's already sorted, re-sort the data in the opposite direction.

structuredContent.leadBold: When it provides value, let people click a column heading to sort a table view based on that column.
structuredContent.remainder: If people click the heading of a column that's already sorted, re-sort the data in the opposite direction.

content.text: Let people resize columns. Data displayed in a table view often varies in width. People appreciate resizing columns to help them concentrate on different areas or reveal clipped data.

structuredContent.remainder: Data displayed in a table view often varies in width. People appreciate resizing columns to help them concentrate on different areas or reveal clipped data.

content.text: Consider using alternating row colors in a multicolumn table. Alternating colors can help people track row values across columns, especially in a wide table.

structuredContent.leadBold: Consider using alternating row colors in a multicolumn table.
structuredContent.remainder: Alternating colors can help people track row values across columns, especially in a wide table.

content.text: Use an outline view instead of a table view to present hierarchical data. An outline view looks like a table view, but includes disclosure triangles for exposing nested levels of data. For example, an outline view might display folders and the items they contain.

structuredContent.leadBold: Use an outline view instead of a table view to present hierarchical data.
structuredContent.remainder: An outline view looks like a table view, but includes disclosure triangles for exposing nested levels of data. For example, an outline view might display folders and the items they contain.

content.text: tvOS

Confirm that images near a table still look good as each row highlights and slightly increases in size when it becomes focused. A focused row's corners can also become rounded, which may affect the appearance of images on either side of it. Account for this effect as you prepare images, and don't add your own masks to round the corners.

structuredContent.leadBold: Confirm that images near a table still look good as each row highlights and slightly increases in size when it becomes focused.
structuredContent.remainder: A focused row's corners can also become rounded, which may affect the appearance of images on either side of it. Account for this effect as you prepare images, and don't add your own masks to round the corners.

content.text: watchOS

When possible, limit the number of rows. Short lists are easier for people to scan, but sometimes people expect a long list of items. For example, if people subscribe to a large number of podcasts, they might think something's wrong if they can't view all their items. You can help make a long list more manageable by listing the most relevant items and providing a way for people to view more.

structuredContent.leadBold: When possible, limit the number of rows.
structuredContent.remainder: Short lists are easier for people to scan, but sometimes people expect a long list of items. For example, if people subscribe to a large number of podcasts, they might think something's wrong if they can't view all their items. You can help make a long list more manageable by listing the most relevant items and providing a way for people to view more.

content.text: Constrain the length of detail views if you want to support vertical page-based navigation. People use vertical page-based navigation to swipe vertically among the detail items of different list rows. Navigating in this way saves time because people don't need to return to the list to tap a new detail item, but it works only when detail views are short. If your detail views scroll, people won't be able to use vertical page-based navigation to swipe among them.

structuredContent.leadBold: Constrain the length of detail views if you want to support vertical page-based navigation.
structuredContent.remainder: People use vertical page-based navigation to swipe vertically among the detail items of different list rows. Navigating in this way saves time because people don't need to return to the list to tap a new detail item, but it works only when detail views are short. If your detail views scroll, people won't be able to use vertical page-based navigation to swipe among them.

Related

cells.content: Updated to include guidance for visionOS.
Updated guidance to reflect changes in watchOS 10.

pages.pageSummary: This is a single long-scrolling documentation page from Apple's Human Interface Guidelines covering lists and tables. It explains how to use lists and tables to present data in columns and rows, with best practices for content organization, styling, and platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS. The page includes visual examples, API references, and links to related developer documentation.

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Apple Developer Navigation with Design section active
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple mega-menu footer with legal links

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduces lists and tables as UI components that present data in rows, explaining their use cases for navigation hierarchies, content display, and data management in apps across all Apple platforms.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: General guidance on using lists and tables effectively: prefer text content, support editing when appropriate, and provide clear feedback on selection.

sections.title: Content
sections.summary: Guidelines for table content: keep text succinct, preserve readability with truncation, and use descriptive column headings.

sections.title: Style
sections.summary: Styling recommendations including choosing appropriate list/table styles, row styles, proper use of info buttons vs disclosure indicators, and avoiding index conflicts with trailing controls.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS, iPadOS, visionOS
subsections.summary: Guidance specific to iOS/iPadOS/visionOS: use info buttons for details, disclosure indicators for navigation.

subsections.title: macOS
subsections.summary: macOS-specific guidance: column sorting, resizable columns, alternating row colors, and outline views for hierarchical data.

subsections.title: tvOS
subsections.summary: tvOS considerations: account for focus state highlighting and row size changes when preparing images.

subsections.title: watchOS
subsections.summary: watchOS guidance: limit row counts, constrain detail view length for vertical page-based navigation.

sections.summary: Platform-specific implementation guidance covering unique behaviors and requirements for each Apple platform.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to related HIG topics: Collections, Outline views, Layout.

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to API documentation: List (SwiftUI), Tables (SwiftUI), UITableView (UIKit), NSTableView (AppKit).

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Link to WWDC video: Stacks, Grids, and Outlines in SwiftUI.

sections.summary: Collection of related resources including HIG cross-references, API documentation links, and educational videos.

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Document revision history showing visionOS guidance added June 21, 2023 and watchOS 10 updates added June 5, 2023.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows a standard Apple HIG structure: it begins with an introduction and hero image explaining what lists and tables are, then provides general best practices, followed by content-specific guidelines, styling recommendations with visual examples, platform-specific considerations for each Apple OS, a resources section with links to related content and developer documentation, and concludes with a changelog documenting recent updates.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that presents data in a single column of rows, often used for navigation hierarchies
A UI component that presents data in one or more columns of rows, supporting selection, editing, and sorting
A detail disclosure button that reveals more information about a row's content without navigating away
A chevron accessory that indicates tapping will navigate to the next level in a hierarchy
A table style in iOS/iPadOS that uses headers, footers, and spacing to separate groups of data
A table-like view with disclosure triangles for exposing nested levels of hierarchical data
A layout that shows multiple views side by side, often combining a list with a detail view
An alternative to tables for displaying items that vary widely in size or for large numbers of images
Alphabetical list displayed vertically at trailing edge for quick navigation to sections
A state in iOS/iPadOS where users can select, reorder, add, or delete table items
watchOS feature allowing vertical swipes between detail views of different list items

keyFindings: Tables are best suited for text content; use collections for images or varied-size items
Info buttons show details about current item; disclosure indicators navigate to child views
Avoid combining table indexes with trailing row controls due to interaction conflicts
macOS tables should support column sorting, resizing, and consider alternating row colors
tvOS focus states affect row size and corner rounding - prepare images accordingly
watchOS lists should be short; detail views should be non-scrolling for vertical page navigation
Different platforms have different table styles: grouped (iOS), elliptical (watchOS), bordered (macOS)
Always provide clear selection feedback appropriate to the action (navigation vs toggle)
Use middle ellipsis truncation to preserve both start and end of content when space is limited

designDecisions.decision: Use disclosure indicators for hierarchical navigation
designDecisions.rationale: Disclosure indicators clearly communicate that tapping will reveal child content or the next level in a hierarchy

designDecisions.decision: Use info buttons for showing additional details
designDecisions.rationale: Info buttons indicate that tapping reveals more information about the current item without navigating away
Both index and controls like disclosure indicators appear on the trailing side, making it difficult to use one without accidentally activating the other

designDecisions.decision: Use alternating row colors in macOS multicolumn tables
designDecisions.rationale: Helps users track row values across multiple columns, especially in wide tables
Short lists are easier to scan on small screens; long lists should show most relevant items first with option to view more

designDecisions.decision: Keep watchOS detail views short for vertical page navigation
designDecisions.rationale: Vertical page-based navigation only works with non-scrolling detail views; scrolling content prevents this navigation pattern
